body_html:
Note that definition of Pow op means that all types are the same

REGISTER_OP("Pow")
    .Input("x: T")
    .Input("y: T")
    .Output("z: T")

_op_def_lib.apply_op is not smart enough to figure out that -83.56^1.5 is complex, so that all inputs must also be treated as complex. This is similar #7170 and the lesson is that except for a few common special cases, you must specify dtype explicitly.

This works

a = tf.constant(-83.56, dtype=tf.complex64)
b = tf.constant(1.5, dtype=tf.complex64)
tf.pow(a, b).eval()   #=> (9.1085985e-06-763.83142j)

Note that definition of Pow op means that all types are the same
REGISTER_OP("Pow")
    .Input("x: T")
    .Input("y: T")
    .Output("z: T")

_op_def_lib.apply_op is not smart enough to figure out that -83.56^1.5 is complex, so that all inputs must also be treated as complex. This is similar #7170 and the lesson is that except for a few common special cases, you must specify dtype explicitly.
This works
a = tf.constant(-83.56, dtype=tf.complex64)
b = tf.constant(1.5, dtype=tf.complex64)
tf.pow(a, b).eval()   #=> (9.1085985e-06-763.83142j)
body:
Note that definition of `Pow` op means that all types are the same

```
REGISTER_OP("Pow")
    .Input("x: T")
    .Input("y: T")
    .Output("z: T")
```

`_op_def_lib.apply_op` is not smart enough to figure out that -83.56^1.5 is complex, so that all inputs must also be treated as complex. This is similar https://github.com/tensorflow/tensorflow/issues/7170 and the lesson is that except for a few common special cases, you must specify `dtype` explicitly.

This works

```
a = tf.constant(-83.56, dtype=tf.complex64)
b = tf.constant(1.5, dtype=tf.complex64)
tf.pow(a, b).eval()   #=> (9.1085985e-06-763.83142j)
```
